coredata.dc:title: An exafs study of aqueous cyanocuprate(I) solutions with a position-sensitive photodiode array
coredata.dc:creator: Sano, Mitsuru
Maruo, Tetsuya
Yamatera, Hideo
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
Aqueous cyanocuprate solutions have been studied with a laboratory EXAFS apparatus. EXAFS spectra obtained for [Cu(CN)3]2− and [Cu(CN)4]3− solutions are analyzed by the curve-fitting method. A comparison with solid cyano complexes gives the structural parameters of aqueous cyanocuprates.

Introduction Tlie EXAFS technique is suited to studying the local environment of an X-ray absorbing atom in solids and liquids [1 ]. and its development is expected to accelerate structural studies in solution chemistry. However, since EXAFS oscillations are usually only a few percent or less of the absorption coefficients, we need to measure the absorption coefficient of a sample with high accuracy as a function of the X-ray wave- length over the spectral region concerned. Although synchrotron radiation is evidently of great value in EXAFS spectroscopy, the utilization of a synchrotron radiation facility is inevitably under various restric- tions as to place and time. Having a laboratory EXAFS spectrometer is a great advantage if it can provide X- ray spectra of satisfactory quality in a tolerable mea- suring time. One approach to a laboratory EXAFS system is to improve the data collection efficiency by simultaneously measuring the intensities of X-rays over the spectral region concerned by using a system * Adjunct Professor at the Institute for Molecular Science (April 1981-March 1983). composed of a dispersing crystal and a position-sensi- tive detector. In a previous paper [2], we reported an EXAFS study of the hydrated Cu2"*" ion with a laboratory system equipped with a position-sensitive detector; however, the spectra were of low signal-to- noise ratio and their Fourier functions were not suf- ficiently reliable ^- Improvement of the apparatus has been carried out by changing the electronic circuit of the pre-amplifier, adjusting the timing of the AD converter, cooling the SSPA, and so on. We report an investigation using a laboratory EXAFS apparatus on the structure of the aqueous solutions ofcyano- cuprates(I). It is well known that the Cv^ ion forms various cyano complexes. The SSPA. consisting of 512 photodiodes and MOS switches, is used as a one-dimensional X-ray detector; X-rays of different wavelengths can be detected by different channels of the SSPA.
